intro: Iberis delphinensis, commonly known as the Delphinian candytuft, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of southern Europe. It belongs to the Brassicaceae family, which includes many other flowering plants with distinctive four-petaled flowers. The plant typically grows to a height of about 30–60 centimeters and produces clusters of small, white or pale blue flowers in spring. Its leaves are simple, alternate, and covered in a fine layer of white hairs, giving them a silvery appearance. Iberis delphinensis is often cultivated in gardens for its ornamental value and hardy nature.
